Zimbabwe - Petina Gappah

The Mupandawana Dancing Champion

Published

December 28, 2021

Zimbabwe: Petina Gappah

Petina Gappah is an Geneva-based international trade lawyer who has written poignant, humane and funny collection of stories about her home country, Zimbabwe. Her first collection of stories, An Elegy for Easterly was a winner of the Guardian First Book Award in 2009. Gappah‚Äôs collection of 13 stories, An Elegy for Easterly, tells of the lives of people, rich and poor, caught up in events over which they have little control.

Story

  1. The Mupandawana Dancing Champion

  2. Petina Gappah reads her own story Weblink to audio

Themes

  • Poverty and Unemployment
  • Inflation and Purchasing Power
  • Incompetent and Corrupt Government
  • Silliness of High-Ranking Officials
  • Music, Dance and pursuits of common people
  • Humour as a Defence Mechanism

Notes and References

Additional Material

The Guardian. 5 Sept 2015. Interview with Petina Gappah. I‚Äôve written a very Zimbabwean story.

Song for the Story!

Billy Joel‚Äôs Allentown from his 1982 album The Nylon Curtain:
> About Allentown

‚ÄúAllentown‚Äù is a song by American singer Billy Joel, which was the lead track on Joel‚Äôs The Nylon Curtain (1982) album, accompanied by a conceptual music video. Upon its release, and especially in subsequent years, ‚ÄúAllentown‚Äù emerged as an anthem of blue-collar America, representing both the aspirations and frustrations of America‚Äôs working class in the late 20th century.


Well we‚Äôre living here in Allentown
And they‚Äôre closing all the factories down
Out in Bethlehem they‚Äôre killing time
Filling out forms
Standing in line
Well our fathers fought the Second World War
Spent their weekends on the Jersey Shore
Met our mothers in the USO1
Asked them to dance
Danced with them slow
And we‚Äôre living here in Allentown

But the restlessness was handed down
And it‚Äôs getting very hard to stay

Well we‚Äôre waiting here in Allentown
For the Pennsylvania we never found
For the promises our teachers gave
If we worked hard
If we behaved

So the graduations hang on the wall
But they never really helped us at all
No they never taught us what was real
Iron and coal
And chromium steel
And we‚Äôre waiting here in Allentown

But they‚Äôve taken all the coal from the ground
And the union people crawled away

Every child has a pretty good shot
To get at least as far as their old man got
But something happened on the way to that place
They threw an American flag in our face

Well I‚Äôm living here in Allentown
And it‚Äôs hard to keep a good man down
But I won‚Äôt be giving up today

And we‚Äôre living here in Allentown
